chapter: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question:
Question 1: A 68-year-old woman sustained a fracture of the proximal humerus and injured the axillary 
artery. She began bleeding into the fascia around it. Where is this fascia derived from?

options.c: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.explanation:
The fascia around the axillary vessels and brachial plexus is called the axillary sheath. It is derived 
from the prevertebral fascia. Clinical correlation: • In a brachial plexus nerve block, the axillary sheath localizes the anesthetic solution to the nerve 
plexus. • Chronic retropharyngeal abscess in TB may spread to the axilla or to the superior mediastinum. 
But it never spreads to the posterior mediastinum because prevertebral fascia fuses to restrict the 
spread.
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question: Question 2: Identify the structure labelled in the diagram below.
questions.explanation:
Structure labelled in the picture is artery piercing the clavipectoral fascia called thoracoacromial 
artery. 647 
Sold by @itachibot Clavipectoral fascia envelops the subclavius and pectoralis minor. Medially it forms 
the costocoracoid ligament. Laterally it is connected to the axillary fascia by suspensory ligament 
of axilla (Gerdy's ligament). The structures piercing clavipectoral fascia are: • 1 vein: Cephalic vein • 1 artery: Thoracoacromial artery (associated veins and lymphatics) • 1 nerve: Lateral pectoral nerve.
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question:
Question 3: 641 
Sold by @itachibot A patient presents with severe radicular pain of the upper extremity due to compression of 
the radial nerve in a space around the shoulder joint. Which of the following is false regarding 
this space?

options.a: Superior border is by teres major
options.b: It contains the circumflex scapular vessels
options.c: Lateral border is by shaft of humerus
options.d: Medial border is by long head of triceps

questions.explanation:
The space around the shoulder joint where the radial nerve may be compressed is the triangular 
interval. It contains the profunda brachii vessels.
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question:
Question 4: A 52-year-old woman presented with weakness of shoulder movements. Investigations 
revealed quadrangular space syndrome. Which of the following nerve is likely to be affected?
questions.explanation:
The axillary nerve is likely to be affected as it is one of the contents of the quadrangular space. Quadrangular space syndrome is a condition is caused by hypertrophy or fibrosis of the 
quadrangular space muscles which impinge on the axillary nerve. Patients present with weakness 
of the shoulder movements.
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not a content of cubital fossa?
questions.explanation:
Bicipital aponeurosis is not a content, it forms the roof of cubital fossa. Biceps tendon is a content 
of cubital fossa. 648 
Sold by @itachibot Note - The Radial nerve is given as content of the cubital fossa in some books, in others, it's 
excluded as a content of cubital fossa due to its extreme lateral position.
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient presented with tenderness in the region shown below following a fall onto an 
outstretched hand. Which of the following forms the roof of this region? 642 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The marked region is the anatomical snuffbox. The superficial branch of radial nerve forms the 
roof of the anatomical snuffbox. Tenderness in this region is suggestive of a scaphoid fracture, a 
common injury after a fall on an outstretched hand. Anatomical snuffbox boundaries: Lateral wall: • Abductor pollicis longus (APL), • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) Medial wall: • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL). Roof: • Cephalic vein • Superficial branch of radial nerve Floor: • Radial styloid, Scaphoid, Trapezium, and 1st Metacarpal. Only content: Radial artery 649 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box?

options.a: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
options.b: Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
options.c: Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
options.d: Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

questions.explanation:
The lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box is formed by extensor pollicis brevis and 
abductor pollicis longus. Boundaries of the anatomical snuffbox: • Lateral wall: • Abductor pollicis longus (APL) • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) • Medial wall: • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) 650 
Sold by @itachibot • Roof: • Cephalic vein • Superficial branch of the radial nerve • Floor: • Radial styloid, scaphoid, trapezium, and 1st metacarpal Only content: Radial artery
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question:
Question 8: A 56-year-old woman presents with tingling and numbness in her hands. The symptoms get 
worse at night and when she's at work using her computer. The affected structure contains all 
of the following except:
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of carpal tunnel syndrome. The carpal tunnel does not 
contain flexor carpi ulnaris tendon (FCU). Carpal tunnel contents (1– structures): Also can be taken as 4 structures only if FDP and FDS are 
counted as 2 structures. • Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP-4 tendons). • Flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS-4 tendons). • Flexor pollicis longus (FPL-1 tendon). • Median nerve between tendons of FDP and FDS. Superficial to the carpal tunnel and the flexor retinaculum, the ulnar artery and ulnar nerve pass 
through the ulnar tunnel or Guyon's canal.
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question:
Question 9: Which among the following is false regarding flexor retinaculum or transverse carpal 
ligament?

options.a: It is medially attached to pisiform and hook of hamate
options.b: It is laterally attached to scaphoid and trapezium
options.c: It splits into a medial superficial slip and a lateral deep slip
options.d: Flexor carpi radialis is the only content in the medial slip

questions.explanation:
Flexor carpi radialis is the only content in the lateral slip, not medial slip. 651 
Sold by @itachibot Flexor retinaculum (carpal tunnel): 1– structures in total. • 4 tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS), 4 tendons of flexor digitorum profundus 
(FDP), both in a common synovial sheath (in ulnar bursa). • 1 Median nerve • 1 Flexor pollicis longus (FPL) with its synovial sheath (in radial bursa). Medial superficial slip of flexor retinaculum (called volar carpal ligament): • Volar carpal ligament forms the "Guyon's canal" • Guyon's canal contains ulnar nerve and vessels. Lateral deep slip of flexor retinaculum: • Flexor carpi radialis (FCR) tendon is the only content. Flexor retinaculum has 4 attachments: • Medially: • Pisiform • ˜ook of the hamate • Laterally: • Tubercles of scaphoid • Trapezium 652 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is not present in the fourth compartment of the extensor retinaculum?
questions.explanation:
Extensor pollicis longus is not present in the fourth compartment of the extensor 
retinaculum. Posterior interosseous nerve and anterior interosseous artery are present in the 
fourth compartment. Extensor retinaculum attachments: • Medially - Pisiform and triquetral. • Laterally - Anterior border of the radius.
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is false about dorsal digital expansion?

options.a: Base of the expansion is at the MCP
options.b: Wing tendons refer to the attachment of extensor digitorum
options.c: The central slip of the extensor tendon is attached to the base of middle phalanx
options.d: The collateral slips are attached to the base of distal phalanx

questions.explanation:
Wing tendons refer to the insertion of lumbricals and interossei to the corners of the dorsal digital 
expansion or simply extensor expansion. 653 
Sold by @itachibot Dorsal digital expansion/ Extensor expansion: • Formation: By extensor tendons expanding "extensor expansion" • Location: Back of digits "dorsal digital expansion" • Extensors making the expansion: ED, EPL (extensor digitorum and extensor pollicis longus) • Muscles joining the expansion: EDM, EI, EPB (extensor digiti minimi, extensor indicis, and 
extensor pollicis brevis) Extensor expansion triangular hood attachments: (The shape of expansion) • Apex: Distal phalanx • Central region: Middle phalanx (in the thumb, attached to proximal phalanx) • Corner of the base: Sides of MCP joint (in the thumb, attached to muscles) • Extensor hood: Lumbrical, interossei, and extensor digitorum muscles (in the thumb, the 
adductor pollicis and abductor pollicis brevis muscles)
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient presents with pain in one of her fingers. Kanavel's sign is positive. Which of the 
following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Kanavel's sign is suggestive of tenosynovitis. Clinically, it can distinguish infectious tenosynovitis from superficial or localized abcess. Kanavel's sign has the following effects - • Tenderness over affected tendon • Fusiform swelling over affected tendon • The affected finger is in slight flexion • Pain on passive extension of the affected finger 654 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question:
Question 13: An infection of the finger as in the image below is most likely to spread to which of the 
following spaces?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows an infection, paronychia, of the middle finger. It can spread into the 
mid-palmar space. Infections of the: • Ring and middle finger spread into the mid-palmar space • Index finger to thenar space • Little finger spread to ulnar bursa and mid palmar space. 655 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is not the content of the mid-palmar space?
questions.explanation:
The 1st lumbrical is not a content of the mid-palmar space. The 1st lumbrical is related to the FDP (flexor digitorum profundus) tendon of the index 
(2nd finger). Thus, it lies in the thenar space. The 2nd, 3rd, and 4th lumbricals are related to the FDP of the middle (3rd finger), ring (4th 
finger), and little (5th finger) respectively. Thus, they lie in the mid-palmar space.
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb

questions.question:
Question 15: 645 
Sold by @itachibot A patient with the following infection in the finger requires incision and drainage as it can 
lead to all of the following except:

options.a: Fibrous stroma is absent beneath the areola
options.b: Alveolar epithelium is columnar in the resting phase

questions.explanation:
The given image shows an infection of the pulp space of the finger or whitlow. It requires incision 
and drainage because when neglected, whitlow can lead to necrosis of the distal 4/5th of the 
terminal phalanx. It does not cause necrosis of the entire phalanx because the proximal 
1/5th escapes as in this part the artery does not cross the fibrous septa. The pulp space of fingers contains subcutaneous fat arranged in tight compartments. These 
compartments are formed by fibrous septa extending from the skin to the periosteum of the 
terminal phalanx. 656 
Sold by @itachibot Whitlow or pulp space infections are treated by a lateral incision and drainage. Its complications 
are: • Ischemic necrosis of the distal 4/5th of terminal phalanx due to vessel occlusion. • Osteomyelitis • Flexor tenosynovitis • Septic arthritis of DIP (distal interphalangeal joint) 657 
Sold by @itachibot Breast
questions.chapter_heading: Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb
